Topic: Illustrate plants with and without water.
CAN: The student can illustrate a plant with some elements indicating it is healthy, such as a few green leaves or a mostly upright stem.
The student can depict a plant that is drooping or has some brown or yellow leaves to suggest it lacks water.
The student can make a basic comparison between two plants, one watered and one without, though details may be incomplete or minimal.
CANNOT: The student may not clearly show vibrant colors for a healthy plant, failing to use bright green or may mix colors erroneously *(student struggles with color usage)*.

The student might depict a wilted plant but incorrectly represent all leaves as green, without showing browning or yellowing *(student doesn't fully grasp changes in leaf color due to lack of water)*.

The student may inconsistently apply elements like stem strength and leaf color across different parts of the drawing, leading to mixed signals in their representation *(student has partial understanding but lacks precision)*.
Patterns of change in plant condition with and without water could be unclear or missing, as the student might not connect these visually *(student understands some changes but not all)*.
